page.textbox:
Testimony of Sidney M. Wolfe MD and Elizabeth Barbehenn, Ph.D., Public Citizen’s Health Research Group FDA Non-Prescription and Endocrine and Metabolic Drug Advisory Committees Hearing on Possible Switch of Orlistat to OTC Status January 23, 2006
Testimony of Sidney M. Wolfe MD
and Elizabeth Barbehenn, Ph.D.,
Public Citizen’s Health Research Group
FDA Non-Prescription and Endocrine
and Metabolic Drug Advisory Committees
Hearing on Possible Switch of
Orlistat to OTC Status
January 23, 2006

Principles to Consider When Deciding on an Rx-to-OTC Switch: Application in the Case of Orlistat
Principles to Consider When Deciding
on an Rx-to-OTC Switch:
Application in the Case of Orlistat

1. Ease / possibility of self-diagnosis
1. Ease / possibility of self-diagnosis

The actual use trial demonstrated that a significant proportion of people choosing orlistat were not very overweight. FDA data from the trial shows that in age groups 36-40 and 41-45 years, 16% of women had starting BMI’s of less than 25.3 kg/m2 and 26.4 kg/m2, respectively. Almost one-third of women had a BMI of less than 30 kg/m2. Self diagnosis, or the lack thereof, of conditions as diabetes, hypertension, often associated with obesity is also a problem.
The actual use trial demonstrated that a significant
proportion of people choosing orlistat were not very
overweight. FDA data from the trial shows that in
age groups 36-40 and 41-45 years, 16% of women
had starting BMI’s of less than 25.3 kg/m2 and
26.4 kg/m2, respectively. Almost one-third of
women had a BMI of less than 30 kg/m2. Self
diagnosis, or the lack thereof, of conditions as
diabetes, hypertension, often associated with
obesity is also a problem.

Ease / possibility of self-diagnosis
Ease / possibility of self-diagnosis

Current research on cardiovascular risk stresses assessment of global risk rather than focusing simply on treating just one possible risk factor. This explains the current labeling on prescription orlistat: “The long-term effects of orlistat on morbidity or mortality associated with obesity have not been established”. The need to consider all factors including hypertension, diabetes, smoking, family history and others is one of the major arguments against OTC availability of anti-hypertensive, cholesterol- lowering, diabetes and weight reduction drugs.
Current research on cardiovascular risk
stresses assessment of global risk rather than
focusing simply on treating just one possible
risk factor. This explains the current labeling on
prescription orlistat: “The long-term effects of
orlistat on morbidity or mortality associated with
obesity have not been established”. The need
to consider all factors including hypertension,
diabetes, smoking, family history and others is
one of the major arguments against OTC
availability of anti-hypertensive, cholesterol-
lowering, diabetes and weight reduction drugs.

GSK explaining why blood pressure and serum lipids were not included in integrated efficacy summary:
GSK explaining why blood pressure and serum
lipids were not included in integrated efficacy
summary:

“..mainly because the [OTC] indication is to promote weight loss and all other benefits achieved from orlistat would be most properly handled under the supervision of a physician.”
“..mainly because the [OTC] indication is to
promote weight loss and all other benefits
achieved from orlistat would be most properly
handled under the supervision of a physician.”

FDA Response to GSK Statement
FDA Response to GSK Statement

• “GSK seems to be saying that overweight
• “GSK seems to be saying that overweight

individuals with weight-related co-morbidities such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension or dyslipidemia are inappropriate candidates for OTC orlistat because weight loss in such patients will require management of a physician to ensure that such changes will favorably alter overall cardiovascular risks.”
individuals with weight-related co-morbidities
such as type 2 diabetes, hypertension or
dyslipidemia are inappropriate candidates for
OTC orlistat because weight loss in such
patients will require management of a
physician to ensure that such changes will
favorably alter overall cardiovascular risks.”

FDA review by J. Golden MD, page 22
FDA review by J. Golden MD, page 22

Further FDA response
Further FDA response

• It is difficult to imagine the proposed
• It is difficult to imagine the proposed

dichotomization of the target population into mildly-to-moderate overweight adults with and without weight-related co-morbidities ...succeeding in the real world
dichotomization of the target population into
mildly-to-moderate overweight adults with
and without weight-related co-morbidities
...succeeding in the real world

FDA review by J. Golden MD, page 22
FDA review by J. Golden MD, page 22

2. Self-limited or chronic condition
2. Self-limited or chronic condition

This is relevant to treatment duration, the evolution of the disease and the occurrence of adverse reactions/ interactions, that may require physician monitoring. In the case of orlistat, the evolution or co-existence of diabetes, hypertension or the need for frequent long- term INR monitoring if on warfarin are serious problems.
This is relevant to treatment duration, the
evolution of the disease and the
occurrence of adverse reactions/
interactions, that may require physician
monitoring. In the case of orlistat, the
evolution or co-existence of diabetes,
hypertension or the need for frequent long-
term INR monitoring if on warfarin are
serious problems.

Findings from Actual Use Study
Findings from Actual Use Study

465 of 681 (68%) of eligible subjects had one or more labeled exclusions including 24.4% with hypertension, 6.8% taking diabetes medication and 2.1% taking warfarin
465 of 681 (68%) of eligible subjects had one or
more labeled exclusions including 24.4% with
hypertension, 6.8% taking diabetes medication
and 2.1% taking warfarin

Of 247 subjects with conditional labeled exclusions, only 32% correctly chose not to use or said they would consult a health professional first
Of 247 subjects with conditional labeled
exclusions, only 32% correctly chose not to use
or said they would consult a health professional
first

Correct multivitamin use never exceeded 54%
Correct multivitamin use never exceeded 54%

3. Benefit / risk ratio and its evaluation
3. Benefit / risk ratio and its evaluation

This is related to # 1 and #2 because the difficulty of continued evaluation of benefit and risk by the patient--arguably without any input from the physician--can significantly alter this ratio and hamper the ability to keep it favorable for the patient. A risk that might be tolerable under a physician’s supervision may not be so with OTC. The time-related increase in weight also alters the benefit / risk ratio, decreasing benefit while continuing risks.
This is related to # 1 and #2 because the
difficulty of continued evaluation of benefit and
risk by the patient--arguably without any input
from the physician--can significantly alter this
ratio and hamper the ability to keep it favorable
for the patient. A risk that might be tolerable
under a physician’s supervision may not be so
with OTC. The time-related increase in weight
also alters the benefit / risk ratio, decreasing
benefit while continuing risks.

4. Adverse drug reactions or interactions and the ease of detecting them
4. Adverse drug reactions or interactions
and the ease of detecting them

There may be adverse reactions or interactions that may not be fully known to the patient or physician. This presents even more cause for concern than the already-troublesome situation involving prescription-only drugs. The common gastrointestinal adverse reactions and, especially the problems in those using warfarin or cyclosporine exemplify this as does the documented inhibition of fat soluble vitamin absorption.

that may not be fully known to the patient or
physician. This presents even more cause for
concern than the already-troublesome situation
involving prescription-only drugs. The common
gastrointestinal adverse reactions and,
